tenses.title: Present Simple Tense
tenses.explanation: The Present Simple Tense is used to describe habitual actions, general truths, and facts that are always true.

tenses.title: Present Continuous Tense
tenses.example: She is reading a book now.
tenses.explanation: The Present Continuous Tense describes actions happening at the moment of speaking or temporary situations.

tenses.title: Past Simple Tense
tenses.example: They visited the museum last weekend.
tenses.explanation: The Past Simple Tense refers to completed actions that happened at a definite time in the past.

tenses.title: Past Continuous Tense
tenses.example: I was watching TV when she called.
tenses.explanation: The Past Continuous Tense describes ongoing past actions that were interrupted by another action.

tenses.title: Present Perfect Tense
tenses.example: She has lived here for five years.
tenses.explanation: The Present Perfect Tense expresses actions or states that started in the past and continue to the present or recent past actions with relevance now.

tenses.title: Present Perfect Continuous Tense
tenses.example: I have been working since morning.
tenses.explanation: This tense emphasizes the duration of an action that began in the past and continues to the present.

tenses.title: Past Perfect Tense
tenses.example: He had finished the work before I arrived.
tenses.explanation: The Past Perfect Tense refers to an action completed before another past action.

tenses.title: Past Perfect Continuous Tense
tenses.example: They had been playing for an hour before it started to rain.
tenses.explanation: This tense emphasizes the duration of a past action before another past event.

tenses.title: Future Simple Tense
tenses.example: I will travel to London next year.
tenses.explanation: The Future Simple Tense describes actions that will happen in the future.

tenses.title: Future Continuous Tense
tenses.example: This time tomorrow, I will be flying to New York.
tenses.explanation: The Future Continuous Tense shows an action that will be in progress at a certain future time.

conditionals.title: Zero Conditional
conditionals.example: If you heat ice, it melts.
conditionals.explanation: Used for general truths or scientific facts; both clauses are in present simple.

conditionals.title: First Conditional
conditionals.example: If it rains, we will stay indoors.
conditionals.explanation: Used for possible future situations; 'if' clause is present simple, main clause uses 'will' + base verb.

conditionals.title: Second Conditional
conditionals.example: If I were rich, I would buy a mansion.
conditionals.explanation: Used for unreal or hypothetical present or future situations; 'if' clause uses past simple, main clause uses 'would' + base verb.

conditionals.title: Third Conditional
conditionals.example: If she had studied harder, she would have passed the exam.
conditionals.explanation: Used for unreal past situations; 'if' clause uses past perfect, main clause uses 'would have' + past participle.

conditionals.title: Mixed Conditional
conditionals.example: If I had gone to bed earlier, I would not be so tired now.
conditionals.explanation: Combines past condition with present result.

conditionals.title: Conditional with Modal Verbs
conditionals.example: If you need help, you can call me.
conditionals.explanation: Modal verbs can appear in the main clause to express ability, permission, or possibility.

conditionals.title: Omitting 'If' with Inversion
conditionals.example: Had I known, I would have acted differently.
conditionals.explanation: In formal English, 'if' can be omitted with subject-auxiliary inversion.

conditionals.title: Conditional Sentences with 'Unless'
conditionals.example: I won’t go unless you come with me.
conditionals.explanation: 'Unless' means 'if not' and is used to express a negative condition.

conditionals.title: Using 'Provided that' and 'As long as'
conditionals.example: You can stay here provided that you are quiet.
conditionals.explanation: These phrases express a condition or requirement for something to happen.

conditionals.title: Using 'In case'
conditionals.example: Take an umbrella in case it rains.
conditionals.explanation: 'In case' is used to prepare for a possible future event.

passive_voice.title: Present Simple Passive
passive_voice.example: The letters are delivered every morning.
passive_voice.explanation: Used to describe routine actions done to the subject.

passive_voice.title: Past Simple Passive
passive_voice.example: The cake was baked by my mother.
passive_voice.explanation: Used to describe completed actions done to the subject in the past.

passive_voice.title: Present Continuous Passive
passive_voice.example: The house is being cleaned now.
passive_voice.explanation: Used for actions currently happening to the subject.

passive_voice.title: Past Continuous Passive
passive_voice.example: The work was being done when I arrived.
passive_voice.explanation: Used for ongoing past actions done to the subject.

passive_voice.title: Present Perfect Passive
passive_voice.explanation: Used for actions completed recently affecting the present.

passive_voice.title: Future Simple Passive
passive_voice.example: The report will be completed tomorrow.
passive_voice.explanation: Used for actions that will happen to the subject in the future.

passive_voice.title: Modal Passive
passive_voice.example: The problem must be solved immediately.
passive_voice.explanation: Modal verbs can be used with the passive form to show necessity or possibility.

passive_voice.title: Get-Passive
passive_voice.example: He got injured during the match.
passive_voice.explanation: 'Get' can be used instead of 'be' for passive in informal contexts.

passive_voice.title: Passive with Two Objects
passive_voice.example: She was given a gift by her friend.
passive_voice.explanation: When two objects appear, the passive can focus on the indirect object.

passive_voice.title: Passive Infinitive
passive_voice.example: This task is easy to complete.
passive_voice.explanation: Passive form can be used with infinitives to describe capability or possibility.

modal_verbs.title: Can for Ability
modal_verbs.explanation: Used to express ability or skill.

modal_verbs.title: Must for Obligation
modal_verbs.explanation: Expresses a strong obligation or necessity.

modal_verbs.title: May for Permission
modal_verbs.explanation: Used to ask for or give permission.

modal_verbs.title: Should for Advice
modal_verbs.example: You should rest if you're tired.
modal_verbs.explanation: Used to give advice or recommendations.

modal_verbs.title: Could for Past Ability
modal_verbs.example: When I was young, I could run fast.
modal_verbs.explanation: Used to talk about past abilities.

modal_verbs.title: Shall for Suggestions
modal_verbs.example: Shall we go to the park?
modal_verbs.explanation: Used to make offers or suggestions.

modal_verbs.title: Need to for Necessity
modal_verbs.example: You need to finish your homework.

articles.title: Definite Article 'The'
articles.explanation: Used before specific or known nouns.

articles.title: Indefinite Article 'A/An'
articles.example: I saw a cat in the garden.
articles.explanation: Used before nonspecific singular nouns; 'a' before consonant sounds, 'an' before vowel sounds.

articles.title: No Article with Plural Nouns
articles.explanation: Used when talking about things in general.

articles.title: No Article with Uncountable Nouns
articles.explanation: Used when speaking about substances or abstract ideas generally.

articles.title: The Article with Unique Objects
articles.explanation: Used with objects that are one of a kind.

articles.title: The Article with Superlatives
articles.example: She is the best student in the class.

articles.title: The Article with Ordinals
articles.example: This is the first time I’ve visited.

articles.title: No Article with Most Countries
articles.explanation: Country names usually don't take an article.

articles.title: The Article with Some Country Groups
articles.example: The Netherlands is known for its tulips.

articles.title: No Article with Names of Languages

prepositions.title: Prepositions of Time
prepositions.explanation: 'At' for specific times, 'on' for days, 'in' for months or years.

prepositions.title: Prepositions of Place
prepositions.example: The book is on the table.
prepositions.explanation: 'On' indicates surface, 'in' indicates inside, 'at' indicates specific point.

prepositions.title: Prepositions of Direction
prepositions.example: She is going to the school.
prepositions.explanation: Used to show movement towards a place.

prepositions.title: Prepositions with Verbs
prepositions.explanation: Certain verbs are followed by specific prepositions.

prepositions.title: Prepositions with Nouns
prepositions.example: The success of the project depends on teamwork.
prepositions.explanation: Nouns can be followed by particular prepositions.

prepositions.title: Compound Prepositions
prepositions.example: He left because of the rain.

prepositions.title: Prepositions of Cause
prepositions.example: They canceled the picnic due to the storm.
prepositions.explanation: Used to express reason or cause.

prepositions.title: Prepositions of Purpose
prepositions.example: She studies to improve her skills.
prepositions.explanation: Indicate the reason for an action.

prepositions.title: Prepositions of Possession
prepositions.example: The keys of the car are missing.

reported_speech.title: Reporting Statements
reported_speech.explanation: Change pronouns and verb tenses appropriately.

reported_speech.title: Reporting Questions
reported_speech.example: He asked where the station was.
reported_speech.explanation: Use 'asked' and change question word order to statement form.

reported_speech.title: Reporting Commands
reported_speech.example: The teacher told us to study.

reported_speech.title: Changes in Time Expressions
reported_speech.explanation: Time words often change when reporting speech.

reported_speech.title: Reporting Yes/No Questions
reported_speech.example: He asked if I was coming.

reported_speech.title: Reporting Requests
reported_speech.example: She asked me to help her.

reported_speech.title: Reporting Suggestions
reported_speech.example: They suggested going to the park.

reported_speech.title: Reporting Advice
reported_speech.example: She advised me to see a doctor.

reported_speech.title: No Change for Universal Truths
reported_speech.example: He said the earth is round.
reported_speech.explanation: Present tense may stay if the statement is a fact.

questions.title: Yes/No Questions
questions.explanation: Formed with auxiliary verbs followed by the subject.

questions.title: Wh- Questions
questions.explanation: Begin with question words like who, what, where, when, why, how.

questions.title: Tag Questions
questions.explanation: Short questions added to statements for confirmation.

questions.title: Indirect Questions
questions.example: Can you tell me where the station is?
questions.explanation: Polite or formal questions embedded in statements.

questions.title: Choice Questions
questions.example: Do you want tea or coffee?
questions.explanation: Offer choices between two or more options.

questions.title: Negative Questions
questions.explanation: Questions with negation to express surprise or disbelief.

questions.title: Subject Questions
questions.explanation: When the question word is the subject, no auxiliary verb is needed.

questions.title: Object Questions
questions.explanation: When question word is the object, auxiliary verb and subject inversion are used.

questions.title: Embedded Questions
questions.example: I wonder what time it is.
questions.explanation: Questions within statements or other questions.

relative_clauses.title: Defining Relative Clauses
relative_clauses.example: The man who called you is here.
relative_clauses.explanation: Essential information about the noun; no commas.

relative_clauses.title: Non-defining Relative Clauses
relative_clauses.example: My brother, who lives in London, is visiting.

relative_clauses.title: Relative Pronoun 'Who'
relative_clauses.example: She is the teacher who helped me.

relative_clauses.title: Relative Pronoun 'Which'
relative_clauses.example: The book which you gave me is great.

relative_clauses.title: Relative Pronoun 'That'
relative_clauses.example: This is the house that Jack built.
relative_clauses.explanation: Can refer to people, animals, or things in defining clauses.

relative_clauses.title: Omitting the Relative Pronoun
relative_clauses.example: The movie (that) we watched was exciting.
relative_clauses.explanation: In defining clauses, 'that' or 'which' can sometimes be omitted.

relative_clauses.title: Possessive Relative Pronoun 'Whose'
relative_clauses.example: The girl whose bike was stolen is upset.

relative_clauses.title: Relative Adverb 'Where'
relative_clauses.example: This is the place where we met.

relative_clauses.title: Relative Adverb 'When'
relative_clauses.example: I remember the day when we met.

relative_clauses.title: Relative Adverb 'Why'
relative_clauses.example: I don’t know the reason why he left.
